Turns out this guy lied and told my boss I hadn't turned over anything!  I tried to explain to my boss that the superior had lied, but I wasn't believed and my boss didn't care.  The next month the practice had a national meeting, and while my name wasn't mentioned, my boss used "MY" screwup as how the company was losing business, and how we can't have idiots working for us!  I went to him afterwards in private, and asked him what exactly should I have done different?  He said "Just do your f**ing job!"  I told him I thought I was, but I could use some constructive feedback and guidance.  He said I should know how to do my job, and he then walked away.  This was all during the absorbtion of Rapidigm into Fujitsu Consulting.  After this particular trip, I was then demoted, and then a few months later, laid off.

review_title: Risk of redundancy today, perhaps new opportunities in the pipeline
pros: Large international company, wide spectrum of roles with some flexibility to move around if you network and drive it. Some good managers (I have had mixed experiences). Offices all over the UK and internationally. Some roles and mangers support flexible working, some don't. Fair company pension contribution, healthcare, 25 +/- 5 days leave, company car for most management roles, and other benefits. The majority of people I have worked with have been perfectly pleasant. Many employees stay with Fujitsu long term, and many return after leaving because it is generally 'comfortable', though less so today with redundancies.
cons:
Significant restructuring and redundancies; leadership is very selective about what information is released. Some line managers are not good. Work-life balance in some roles can be poor if you want to do a good job. Long term employees will fall far behind market rate. No company share or investment benefits (Japanese company). Appraisal process is a formality, which fails to recognise or reward individual performances. Feeling less like the people company of 10 years ago and culture starting to align more closely with our American competitors.

12 months ago I would have recommended Fujitsu, today I would suggest waiting for the restructuring to complete.

Pay/packages are not as bad as many people seem to think (usually those with less experience of working for some of the other large SIs), but recent loss of final salary pension and no pay awards have obviously been tough and unpopular.
cons:
Too many senior people who don't understand the systems integration/outsourcing business, never mind just the desktop and service desk type work we tend to try and go for.
Far too many people who simply don't care, do as little as possible, who wouldn't understand "ownership" if it bit them, and who never seem to suffer for it.
Company policies on working from home, and working in "fragments" all over the place, mean that people can "hide" successfully for long/frequent periods.
Poor adherence to any kind of process (I hate bureaucracy but sometimes it's just chaos).
Lack of investment in internal systems - leading to huge internal inefficiencies.

pros:
Nice new well equipped office close to transport and shopping
Not limited to one technology area
cons:
Bullying culture (usually in certain teams or individuals like bid or project management teams).

Poor project management , exacerbated by the practice of hiring too many contractors (who don't know the company processes etc they are supposed to manage). 
More is lost from the loss of knowledge and the constant re-learning process than can be gained from the flexibility. You end up managing them more than they manage themselves.

Fujitsu treats employees as a liability rather than an asset, even full time employees are treated like contractors (i.e. disposable).

Constant restructuring.
Regular redundancies without any communication or notice, often based on bean counter decision.

Too many  project managers and account teams trying to trick you into working for free (not wanting you to record against their project) and dishonest about work scope.
Too much time spent chasing project codes just so you can fill out your time sheets.

You role is irrelevant - you are asked to do anything regardless of training or qualifications.

Senior management (particularly GM level) more concerned with finger pointing than solving issues.

All hot desking.

review_title: DO NOT WORK FOR THIS AWFUL COMPANY
job_title: Wintel Technical Service Specialist in Sydney
pros: I worked with a great bunch of people for the most part. If you have a personal issue such as a bereavement, they are very helpful. This is more down to the individual line manager rather than Fujitsu policy though
cons: I worked for Fujitsu for over 8 years. The wages are very poor. Pay rises even if you get one have were always well below inflation. Over time Fujitsu have taken away employee benefits. As two examples only a portion of the bank holidays are now available, the medical benefit now has to be paid for. Fujitsu only seem concerned that you comply with what they want and have no concern about their employees moral. They expect more and more from employees without any financial compensation. I always felt stressed that I had to watch my back constantly because of the back stabbing by management and other teams, this was awful. The senior management are just the worst and have no concern regarding the people that work below them. This includes their own managers below them. The last straw came when the mamagement began taking away overtime that I relied on because of the poor wages. I suspect however, that was due to the fact I stood up for myself. So word of warning, DO NOT stand up to the management. You will be punished for it.

job_title: Cloud Solution Architect in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: good company to work for
cons: not a lot of growth opportunities

pros: FNC is a market leader in optical transport in the US. There is some flexibility in work hours which helps with work/life balance. An on-site gym is popular at lunchtime. FNCs largest customers are AT&T and Verizon so it has a strong customer base for its current prodcut generation.
cons: Employees are siloed - they toil away in the dark and have little opportunity for any real recognition.  You won't get rich at FNC. Upper management is isolated. There is a Japanese expat clique that keeps to themselves. US managers only talk to each other. You won't see them walking around the building talking with anyone. The real decisions are made in Japan - HW development is there too. Japan develops the products and dumps them on FNC to sell in the US.  You are only provided with the information you absolutely need to have - knowledge is power so people don't freely share information. The company has a vested interest in laying you off before 5 years - before you vest in your 401K cause they keep the unvested funds when they get rid of you.

pros:
An excellent company to work for and I love the location, since the office is attached to a shopping centre and close to a park.  They offered me to stay at a hotel for a week until I moved into a Fujitsu owned house (rent costs are above local average however).  The company also offers a type of debit card that can be used in grocery shops and restaurants (as a form of lunch allowance) and they offer medical insurance.

The job itself is typically as you'd expect. You get calls from clients and you have to help them to fix their issues. There's a laid back, yet professional atmostphere around the office and most managers are very nice.
cons: The biggest downside is that the job is not very challenging even though it is a challenge to get your work done in time, since the FJ ticketing system lags very often.

pros:
Good japanese training 
Good people
cons:
Low salary 
No projects
No human respect

review_title: Tough decision to leave Fujitsu, but new leadership refreshing and inspiring.
pros: Company has a lot of potential and people are wonderful..!
cons: Serious challenges with the infrastructure leadership and priorities....or lack thereof.

pros:
1) It has good perks and family - work life balance
2) No hassle in Visa status, they have a good record that their visa does not cancel or rejected since long time.
3) Good education perks and 401k plans
cons:
1) they have limited projects and client
2) As Fujitsu global trying to add efforts of doing dome innovation but Fujitsu America does not bring good clients and work
3) Limited work and no growth at work
4) Once you deployed to client , no one will listen you and poor  resource management team, they don't consider knowledge
5) Every alternate year they wont provide bonus and that is maximum of 2% which is like a peanuts 
6) No Growth in terms of technology, recognition and promotion. hardly one get promotion after spending several years which could potential raise up to 10k.
7) Top management reshuffling a lot, every year Organization changes happened.
8) Every year we see a new sales person is assigned to our account, bad Sales team ever who does not have capacity to bring big clients in USA.

review_title: An Global BODY SHOP company with high billing rates and low job security
job_title: Senior Technical Consultant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Very good Paralegal and HR Services....Competitive salary with the industry if your at senior level. They often give an 2 weeks notice to their bench employees.
cons: Other than good paralegal and HR services this is an Worst company to join. They say tht they are competitors of IBM, EDS, Accenture, Deloitte but they can't find any good projects for months....simply to say its an "BODY SHOP" company like many Indian companies in New Jersey with an Global Name. All the senior level technical guys are Indians who just want high billing and promotions....they wn't care about employee job security and career. The standards are worst over here....Even if you have good recognition from the clients they can layoff... if your on bench for over 3months. They can't find any project nor unable to bodyshop coz of there high rates ($100 per hr) If your got any project with lesser rate they will simply reject it....Its better to join an 85:15 company if are able to get your own projects. This happens to be biggest mistake I ever made in my life joining this BODY SHOP Global company. Please think twice before you join this company. Its an humble advice.

pros:
Good building - although whoever designed it with no ventilation in the toilets??? someone bring a canary in a cage after lunchtimes...
Bonus - your manager is unlikely to talk to you except during your yearly "appraisal", and your weeks will be unencumbered by team meetings or other forms of communication.
cons: Where to start? Toxic and bullying culture, no work life balance, poor salaries and no cost of living increase, absolutely woeful communication, and absurdly top heavy with management (the old joke about the rowing team with eight managers and one rower comes to mind). Staff have no idea what is going on in the company or even their own teams and morale is extremely low, managers are barely able to manage themselves let alone others.  Far too many managers who never go near a customer, instead they are just highly paid admin staff who shuffle paper. Very poor opportunity for advancement. And once you reach a certain age you'll be bypassed for training or other opportunities - yes, age-related discrimination is alive and well too.

pros: Bad managers don't care about the team
cons: Good benefits. Good insurance for family

pros:
* Exposure to leading/bleeding edge technology solutions
* Very fair total compensation plans
* Signs that they might have their organization pieced together cohesively by 2013
cons:
* While communication from the CEO is frequent, mission and vision clear, his VPs and Directors pass on very little else to their troops
* The pieceing together of multiple acquisitions into what is today Fujitsu America has created a hodge-podge of sub-organizations under one banner.  These sub-orgs are not united, communicate very poorly and no one I worked with seemed to have any pride in the organization (collectively Fujitsu America) they represented or sold for.

review_title: Depends on what account you're on.
pros: The work is varied, with lots of different accounts. It's not too hard to get an entry level IT job, which offers a lot of responsibility from the start.
cons:
The pay is low in comparison to other companies. Remember this is FSESL (Fujitsu Services Engineering Services Limited) not to be confused with Fujitsu. FSESL is a fully owned subsidiary of Fujitsu, but unlike Fujitsu, it pays less and offers less to it's employees. 

I mentioned above that the work is varied, this is not necessarily a good point, because you can find yourself on a really bad account, where your work/life balance will become badly affected - due to the amount of travelling up and down the country and unsociable work hours (5pm - 3/4am) etc. This includes overnight stays in hotels etc. Or you could find yourself on a deskside job where the hours are set, Monday - Friday and are reasonable. 

No room for career progression.

review_title: Should be called the SS Titanic
pros: Some of the people at the bottom of the chain are helpful.  Some are complete jerks.  Salaries about about average.  Can't really think of any other pros to working here.
cons:
This place is an absolute disaster!  They are a drowning company in a declining hardware market trying to stay relevant.  Company leadership is the worst I have ever encountered in my 20 + year career.  Bob Pryor is as political an operative as you will ever find.  When he came in he brought in his "FOB's" (Friends of Bob) who, for the most part, are completely ineffective.  Their culture is to beat you and beat you to try and suck more life out of you.  The place is in shambles with very high turnover.  

I used to wake up every morning dreading attending the call after call after call that Fujitsu spawns.  I finally quit when it started to affect my health.  I have since found another company in the Bay Area that is FANTASTIC to work for and has made me realize just how horrible FAI was.  So glad I left FAI!  

My advice to potential employees is to RUN AWAY from this company as fast as possible!  Pick just about any other company out there and they will be better than FAI!

review_title: One person ruining this great company
pros:
Best infrastructure
Work from home policy
Supportive clients
Renowned brand
cons:
Where do I start? I worked in night shift for finance process which is being managed by a so called delivery manager. I still wonder, who hired this guy who is the most unprofessional person I met in corporate. First of all, he takes everything personally, always doubts people, makes random allegations. If a person by mistake comes on his radar, this manager makes that person leave the company by harassment, threatening and targetting. Lot of people have complained against this guy but hr team acts as per the directions of delivery team so no point in seeking their help. This manager is a perfect example of office politics, bias ness and mostly abuse of his power. He always promotes those who are goodie goodie with him. I have personally experienced his wrath just because he felt I was conspiring against him. I really felt bad while learning this company because the client was very supportive and motivated me. It always surprised me that how come this guy is allowed to ruin people's career who join this great company for chasing their dream. To add more, this guy is given more bigger role. What 
an irony.

review_title: Global organization with a focus on offshoring
pros:
My direct manager was supportive, engaged and focused on solving problems with the customer.  
FAI is a huge corporation with a global presence that allows avenues for multiple possibilities when it comes to satisfying a client's request.  
Lots of dedicated people available to be contacted to help solve a client issue.  
Friendly people willing to help -- all you have to do is ask.
cons:
Relies more on solving problems through quantity vs. quality.  It's hard to find top-notch technical people and the preference is to throw more people at a problem or cycle through mediocre technical staff at a client site.
Recruiters tend to promise more than they are authorized to deliver.  Make sure you get there promises in writing with the employee agreement before signing.
Lots of layers and levels of approval (as you should expect from a large corporation).
Lack of community feeling and lack of shared knowledge with other consultants in my expertise.  Other than phone calls with my manager, I often felt isolated from the rest of FAI.
Trend towards offshoring more and more parts of the organization -- especially technical staff.

review_title: Fujitsu NZ, its a terrible place to work.
pros:
They paid you money.

Since leaving them my life, health, relationships and my stress levels have improved. Leaving Fujitsu was the best thing I've ever done.
cons:
Everything you do is watched, criticise and ripped apart. Dont bother coming up with ideas on how to improve things. You'll be shot down right away or left to linger in middle management ether of impotence for an age. 

To Fujitsu you are nothing more than a resource to be consumed and discarded when you've got no more to give. 

They've developed a set of 'KPI' in such a way that it is impossible not to fail. Thus preventing you from ever getting a salary raise of any substance.

The upper management love to come and make promises to goals and successes. But those plebs on the front line never see any of it. 

What amazes me is the fact that every single customer is paying for a shocking service that isn't designed to actually fix anything. But rather to maintain the status-quo. Neither improving or getting worse. That way they can milk their government contracted cash cow for all its worth.

review_title: Nice place to work but the work can go pear-shaped and be rather dull.
pros:
Your colleagues are decent people, and make coming back to work in the New Year less unpleasant. Camaraderie, support from colleagues is excellent.

You are wanting to avoid Competitors who treat their people badly; amazing as it sometimes seemed, I've heard our Competitors are even worse on delivery than FS.
cons:
Most projects go pear-shaped after a year and then everyone is in fire-fighting mode; a lot of people have made good careers at trouble-shooting. This is unfortunate, as things should go right first time.

I personally have been on a big project from the start and seen things unravelling in front of my eyes. No-one seemed to know what to do.

Also, little Private Sector work means working at the pace of the Public Sector. Civil Servants are nice folk, but hamstrung by culture and political imperatives.

review_title: Heading down for a second ship wreck
pros: Good Managed Services Teams with dumbest ever Professional Services Teams. Fujitsu Australia (not NZ) have some of the brightest and hardest working Managed Services Engineers. A very good company to learn and move out. Also, a good company to retire.
cons:
Work like mouse and ask for a peanut pay, you will be OK. Old Kaz-Group Management in power, they had a ship wreck while managing Kaz, got sold off to Fujitsu. Strangely, Kaz Group Mgt took over the power. If not replaced, the company might be heading for a second ship wreck. Already lost some major accounts this year to IBM.

Also, the Project (Professional) Services Teams' Architects and Engineers are a bit of joke, majority of PS team members are funitures, waiting for their retirement or wasting time. Weired environment, where MS teams are more technically saavy and brighter than the PS old farts. As stated, if you are a PS Engineer, go to another integrator.

pros: Hard to think of many. Free coffee?
cons: Yesterday’s company, poorly led. Avoid.

pros: There are still some good people left and the company will probably be around for a long time to come so, a steady paycheck is there for those interested in one.
cons: Little to no rewards (pay raises, bonuses, recognition etc.) for going above and beyond, they don't promote much from within so if you have ambitions of moving up you may be disappointed.  Whether they admit it or not they utilize stack ranking practices.  There were good old days but those are long gone and anyone left is either too comfortable or too afraid to look for something better.  Morale is bad, most people have given up.  Leaders appear and disappear through a rotating door of elitist hatchet-men.

review_title: Best career move I ever made.
pros:
I have worked for Fujitsu for around 9 years.  I have had the opportunity to work on a number of different projects from small implementations to one of the largest Oracle implementations in UK.  I joined after a long career in the public sector and was grateful to be taken on without previous private sector consulting experience.  I have an excellent mentor who has helped me develop my Oracle skills and consolidate my knowledge.  You have to be a self-starter and not wait to be told what to do.  Coming from the civil service where the chain of command is much more rigid, this can be a bit disconcerting at first.  
The organisation is family friendly and sensitive to the personal needs of it's employees.  The working atmosphere is excellent, staff are friendly, helpful and have a real desire to do the best for the customer.
cons: I think the first couple of months can be a bit daunting if your job involves remote working.  You may not meet all of your team members for some time and one can feel isolated.  The solution is to keep in touch with team members by phone, Lync etc.

job_title: Service Desk Agent (Former) in Bracknell, England
pros:
Camaraderie, we're all in it together

Some good people on the desk

Certain managers are good to work for/with

 Opportunities to progress do come up

Those willing to learn/ take initiative can progress within the company, I did

Has improved in some aspects in the time I spent there (1.5 years)

Decent basic grounding in technical support, flawed but substantial knowledge base
cons:
Nepotism (or is it just human nature)

Some management clearly brown-nosed their way up with little in the way of technical knowledge

For every good change, there will be a bad/stupid one

Micromanagement of agents, absurd constraints such as how much time per month you can use the toilet/your free time on shift (now a grand total of two hours/ month), insufficient break and lunch times.

Self-defeating constraints and red tape for red tape's sake

Relevant to above, high attrition rate of staff. Many good, competent people give up/move onto greener pastures/ get fired for stupid reasons like being one minute late too many times.

Any rube can walk through the door

Below standard pay compared to equivalent positions, even when promoted

You can just tell many people are depressed and fed up

pros: Big company, Japanese innovation, well established
cons: Silo'd management, slow decision makers

review_title: Ambitious company seeking new opportunities but lacks agility to deliver
job_title: Senior Service Delivery Manager in London, England
pros:
Great place for graduates to cut their teeth across a wide spectrum of roles and gain valuable experience of working with "big player" companies. 
Flexibility to move within the organisation and work with different programs is promoted
General work/life balance is good if your in a position to take advantage of remote working
cons:
Poor project management activities allowed to fester to the point of program collapse. 
No incentive to operate in service delivery on an account running at a loss due to program investment in transformation activities.
Lack of any form of agility or sense of urgency to respond to a private sector customers need is a killer due to the internal operating structure of the company. Using shared services across multiple accounts to keep operating costs to minimum is admirable but not when the effect of implementing a change results in weeks/months of waiting for a customer fix or request for quote to be implemented.

review_title: Friendly, flexible and environmentally friendly company
pros:
My manager and team were great to work with. The job offered a great deal of flexibility and I liked working for a company who cares so much about sustainability and the environment.
The job I had offered great work / life balance and my manager was flexible with my hours and work.
cons:
While they have a lot of good ideals, these are rarely in use on a day to day basis or employees are not encouraged to work towards these ideals. They were meant to be an ITIL company but didn't have any testing strategies or practices.
To compound the issue all Business Analyst and Software Development roles were moved off shore (for any new positions) essentially making team work in my team much more difficult. As our team supported many different timezones a few people worked really crazy hours for not much personal benefit.

job_title: Associate Practice Director in Richardson, TX
pros: The consultants were good, and great to work with.  They can place you into a client, and you can gain a lot of skill very quick.  Fujitsu Consulting is a large firm, and if you like to travel, then you can have a placement just about anywhere.  If you can attach yourself to a large strategic project, then your resume will look rand.  I would leverage Fujitsu Consulting as a place-holder to put onto your resume.
cons: I worked within the MS Practice, and it was managed very poorly.  Within the MS Practice there was complete turnover from management.  Fujitsu is growing the MS Practice by acquisition, and integrating them poorly.  They change the corresponding culture of those firms, into one of staffing, japanese style.  In you are on the bench, then you need to be aware.  They state that they will keep you on the bench for a period of time, but will only support it based on % budget available to keep people on the bench. The Sr. Management looks at consultants as inventory, rather than people.

job_title: Customer Service Engineer in Las Vegas, NV
pros: No office to visit everyday.  Given company vehicle, laptop, and cell phone to perform job duties.  Co-workers are awesome.
cons: Micro-management.  Recently added GPS to vans and restrict your time to idle even though 80% of the job is documentation on their horrible job tracking system.  Evaluations and raises are based on metrics that do not measure your ability to provide customer service, they measure your ability to be a company man.  You can provide the worst customer service, but if you update unnecessary files, if your not idling too long in your van, if you say you fix every problem the first time (even though you didn't), you are guaranteed a salary increase.  When they do come.  Once every 5 years!  Completely disconnected from the company.  Working the front lines with no weapons or protection.  Just a target put on your back!  No bonuses, no Christmas parties, no annual salary increases.

pros: Most of the people in my department were very friendly, helpful, and the middle management was great, very flexible with work life balance
cons: Horrible pay, they do not compensate people who have been loyal to the company for years. Someone with 3 years of experience at Fujitsu America could easily be making 10k more elsewhere. Also, the executives pick favorites and only favor towards them and their departments.  Bonuses are not available to all unless you are one of the "favorites." Very political, catty, and unfair to lower level employees. Also, the facility is disgustingly dirty, dated, and could be redesigned. No opportunities for employee engagements or socials at all. It's especially frustrating when FNC on the other side of the campus gets a half day off, t-shirts, and a celebration for Fujitsu Day, and all Fujitsu America gets is a speech from the CEO about how we need to improve and work harder. Real inspiring.... IT help desk is miserably slow, as well as getting anything approved or done there. Patience is a virtue when working at Fujitsu America. No opportunity for advancement.

pros: great people with the right attitude
cons: Poor executive management who promote friends not the right person

review_title: Reorganizing and cutting their way to failure
pros:
Decent salary and benefits. Excellent co-workers.
Career opportunities abound for the right people.
cons:
Constant churn of reorg after reorg after reorg. 
Too much time spent navel-gazing and not enough time spent taking care of customers. 
Unrealistic budget goals and ruthlessly cutting of teams to achieve them. Short-sighted management of current resources.
Healthcare plan is the worst I have ever seen - all are forced into HRA or HSA; HRA amounts provided are fine for young, healthy people who never see a doctor but ridiculous for anyone else AND they make you jump through hoops even to get all of the amount they agree to provide. Up-front amount decreases and deductible increases every year.
No raises, no bonuses - no sense at all that upper management sees resources as anything other than expendable, disposable, and interchangeable.

review_title: Fujitsu is not good company in every aspect.
pros: The only good things is that Fujitsu office has good greenery.
cons:
Lots of cons. 
1. Less pay and in everything,company is doing cost cutting. Shift allowance is very less.if you want that employee should work good you should focus on employee perspective.
2. Manager is very unprofessional and rude. Only they wants to put their own thoughts and do not want to listen and understand the things. Its very difficult to work with manager.
3. For New joiner there are not good gesture and no one will talk to you, you have to talk and understand. I think there must be some policies for new joiners.
4. Work is good but lots of process is involved. We can understand about the data confidentiality. But lots of process effect technical growth.
5. Management is not good. No appreciation will receive only escalations are coming ..
6. Transport facility is worst. As office location. Is very far from city. Transport facility for shifts should be home pickup . And transport facility should be free for shift.

review_title: One of the best places to work!
pros: Good work life balance.  Friendly people that are genuinely willing to help.  It is a great company if you are looking for 9-5 stability.  Nothing out of the ordinary happens here.  Probably one of the greatest things is the scope of work you are able to do.  Makes the job challenging and time go by quickly.
cons:
No defined career path.  I found it very difficult to get ahead in this company.  I could move horizontally but that was not what I wanted.  I would assume I could obtain this through attrition but I wasn't willing to wait this long.  

The company has many different divisions that do not work collectively.  As such you have a big company that does not leverage the collective ability of the organization creating a barrier for continued growth.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in London, England
pros:
Great people on some accounts.

Experience across an array of technical disciplines.

Wide variety of accounts at the very top of government and some good Private Sector accounts..
cons:
Daily battle with in-house teams - simple requests for changes or decisions take weeks or months to get processed, dangerously disproportionate with the requirements of today’s clients, who need an agile responsive supplier.

Programme directors  follow a reckless pursuit of milestones at the expense of people  - a real shame because rather than empowering and inspiring you so you willingly give that extra percentile,  many PMs either leave or default to self preservation mode, apprension sets in, morale dissipates and creativity dies.

Promotion freeze in 10/11, you will be operating at a single level for years & remuneration doesnt match that of competitors.

review_title: Complete disregard for security and communication to its employees
pros: There are many great individuals that work at Fujitsu, however its simply a numbers game and they are not allowed to innovate properly.
cons: There is a total lack of understanding at the executive level of what the security function plays within the organization.  There hasn't been a proper security structure in the organization for years and there is no clear strategy in that space for moving forward.  If I was a customer I would be very nervous about the security of my systems in the hands of Fujitsu.   Management always say one thing to the employees and then in the back ground do another, very poor communication at the executive level and waffle on their commitments.

review_title: It was a good company to work for at one time.
pros:
Great benefits and good salaries and overall good people to work with.
The company was once one of the best companies to work for.
cons: Bad upper management business decisions is taking a toll in the company's reputation and prestige. For the last five years there has been an average of one RIF per year coupled with the fact that the people that got the boot were not all based on bad performance and because of that they have lost good talented employees. I'm afraid outsourcing more than 50% of the R&D is not going to cut it.

review_title: Mass changes and layoffs coming down the pipe
pros:
Decent paycheck
Gym and cafeteria are on site at FNC in Richardson
Nice HQ in easy to access location in metroplex
cons:
Aging middle management has ruined this company
All the older management don't care or try to be inventive. 
This mindset runs off all the young talent because they are huge roadblocks. 
They are now combining companies across the US to try and do cost savings, retirement offers have gone out to people. 
FAI has been an utter failure for the last ten years yet they are keeping it alive. 
They are starting to think all of IT can now suddenly be sent to the cloud and be supported by India, they couldn't be more wrong. 
It's a cluster mess, unless you need at job stay away.

pros: This used to be a good company to work for.  A company that cared about their employees.  Now you have managers that say plainly "they only want to do what is best for the company", so F the employees.  Well isn't what is best for the company taking care of your employees and making them feel like they are part of the team?  When employees are treated badly how do you expect them to want to do their best or even stay with the company.  SMH
cons:
No support for employees
CEO encourages his managers to lead by fear and intimidation
All VP's except 1 are tyrants and bullies
Employees are only there until they find a better job.  Everyone is looking.

I have worked for Fujitsu a long time and I have never seen the company in this state.  It all began when the current CEO started.  It is a shame to see such a great company go down like  a sinking ship.

review_title: Satisfying and frustrating in equal measure
job_title: Mid Senior Management in London, England
pros: I love this company because of its people. In a 39 year career, my 4 years at Fujitsu have been some of my most rewarding. Not for the salary and benefits, frankly I could (and have) earned much more elsewhere. I love it because I feels that they genuinely value their employees and want you to succeed. Opportunities are there to make an active contribution if you wish and ‘disruptors’ are welcomed
cons: In an increasingly digitised marketplace Fujitsu are struggling to hold their place in the market and are having a bit of a mid life crisis. We must evolve or risk going the way of Nokia etc.... we still have outdated practices and processes that conflict with the new paradigm and that causes disconnects and discomfort especially where there are multiple change initiatives going on across the EMEIA region. Finding clear guidance on the overcomplex go to market offerings is bewilderingly mind bogglingly frustratingly painfully difficult

review_title: Fujitsu Frontech North America: The Land That Time Forgot
pros: It's a paycheck with benefits.  I really have nothing more to add, or as Bugs Bunny once said, "It's a living".
cons: Sycophants are promoted and work little, Engineers aren't educationally qualified, Supervisors have zero leadership skills with no initiative, Management isn't motivated and only collects the paycheck, Workers are treated as mindless drones, pay raises are nonexistent, years of service means nothing, Mass confusion is the norm, little attention is spent improving operating procedures, the left hand never knows what the right hand is doing, favoritism is abound, the Talented are greeted with jealousy, and the Incompetent and Lazy are rewarded.

review_title: If you're considering working for this company, stop and run for the hills
pros: It's a great to place to work if you 1) have no career aspirations, 2) don't mind below market compensation 3) enjoy working with incompetent people 4)  like completely outdated systems that you depend on to perform your job and 5) want to work for executives that are deceitful, manipulative, and have no business being in leadership positions.
cons: This company is just awful.   I'm  not trying to sound like a bitter former employee.  I was not fired or let go.  I voluntarily left Fujitsu America because after being there for over a year I was tired of working in a negative and politically charged environment.  I'm currently employed at another technology company in the SF Bay Area, and it's made me realize how bad it actually was at Fujitsu.  I keep asking myself how in the world did I ever work for Fujitsu America?  The most recent fiasco at Fujitsu is the hiring of a CFO that's unfit, unqualified, and downright incapable of leading the Finance organization.  Who in their right mind would hire someone so incapable - the CEO.  That tells you about the leadership of this company.

review_title: Competes in Optical space on Price, thus all engineering effort goes into Cost Reduction, with minimal Innovation
job_title: Hardware Engineer V in Pearl River, NY
pros: Derives stability from not making wild bets. A Japanese Company which means that (as opposed to American Companies) is not fixated on short-term stock price when making decisions that have a long-term effect.
cons: Fails to anticipate the market direction. Responds to market needs only when proded by a paying customer. A Me-too company. Wins market share by undercutting the competition. Thus, barely makes money. Minimal innovation. All Engineering development efforts goes towards cost reduction. Appears to exist mainly so as to give its parent company (Fujitsu Japan) access the US markets and technology. Key decisions are made is Japan. Key Engineering development is commandeered by the Japanese development team - the leftover development is given to the US shop.

job_title: Network and Computer Systems Administrator in Richardson, TX
pros: Decent Pay, good 401k plan, reasonable holiday hours
cons: only selected group of managers who’ve spent their entire life working in this company acts as a block against any attempt to bring innovation to the organization. Newcomers at any level are viewed with suspicion and any idea they bring with them from the outside is treated with a mixture of fear and contempt. I was accused of providing wrong data based on their own manual but because of the relationship with the big manager and old people who screwed up the manual and commutations processes, there was extra work to prevent mysef from getting fired. In the end, they all realized they were incorrect but came up with some lame excuse. I dont expect an apology from big bosses but really? I wish all the big manager would have behaved in a professional manner, not personal. Just because you like someone does not mean everything they do is right.

job_title: Senior Network Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Good work life balance.
2 weeks shutdown at the end of the year giving some time to relax and de-stress.
Decent benefits and 401k match.
Decent Japanese food served in their cafeteria.
cons:
Highly confused management team leading to a finger-pointing and poorly managed work environment.
De-motivated employees who are looking to exit the company but unable to do so as the poor work environment has sucked out their inner confidence to do so.
No stock options and below market compensation.
Extremely difficult to innovate or to perform in your job as you will need to get several approvals before your project will be green lighted.
Very very slow work environment that does not enourage innovation and will render you useless if you put in more years into this company.
Highly political and back stabbing is rampant throughout the organization even by your own peers and boss.
Management does not communicate to the employees and is not transparent with what's going on leading to high levels of distrust.

pros:
-good as a first job in tech as no experience is required and having a big corporation like Fujitsu on your CV is favourable when looking to go somewhere else
-work with some great people
-in a good location for commuting with good public transport links and on site parking
-on site gym and canteen
cons:
-very low salary
-yearly appraisals where you are required to perform like a clapping seal infront of a board of managers for a potential but very unlikely extra £10 a month
-no career progression, almost feels like you are encouraged to stagnate at the bottom
-many people on 1st line were very technically competent but any suggestions of a move to another team always fell on deaf ears
-culture is very cliquey, the few that do get promotions get them not because they deserve them but because they are friends with managers
-same inner circle of managers/supervisors tend to do absolutely no work whatsoever but are always on peoples backs while they watch youtube videos and gossip amongst themselves all day
-poor job security, in my time there people were made to train their Russian replacements before being made redundant

pros: Being an outsourcing company for a company in Japan, there's always new things to learn and new challenges to conquer. The monetary benefits are great and its quite easy to apply for leaves, though its sometimes abused by employees.
cons:
Employees' career growth is not the focus of this company, typical of a Japanese company. Though there are exceptions especially when you're on the good side of your managers and supervisors, typical of a company in the Philippines. Lots of under-performing who are given endless chances because they'd rather keep a rotten tomato than lose it. Again, typical of a company/business in the Philippines. 

And being typical of an outsourced company, clients don't trust right away and they'd think twice of training staffs to perform projects. It can't be helped when its common in the Philippines for incompetent people to be hired in crucial positions.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in London, England
pros:
Some good people
The company could be great
Lots of offices
Lots of scope to improve
Cheap coffee
cons:
The company has no global business model so offerings are all local and sub scale. The Japanese parent is very insular and doesn't understand what is going on outside Japan

With maybe 1 exception the executive team are all long term Fujitsu people who have no idea what a successful IT  business looks like

The company is mighty confused about what it is. Tries to do everything but ends up not being market leading at anything

It's main business is low value commodity work such as deskside support

It is hugely political, management spend all their time internally and have no concept of customers being at the centre of the business. 

Only just realised that offshore exists

It  has no diversity. It's full of grey middle aged men and hardly and ethnic mix at all

review_title: Actual experience does not match the reputation.
job_title: Senior Product Development Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros: Good customer focus and robust tools.  Many capable professionals (and many more left).  Good benefits.
cons:
Job security is long gone.  Staff is being laid off every 1-2 quarters, going back more than two years now. No real raises and the job promotion process is nothing more than a path on paper.  No promotions to be had.  I gave opportunites one star, should be zero.
 
An IT company that does not pay for professional development for its staff! That's enlightened management.  No certifications paid for due to cutbacks unless you count the chintzy little online e-learning with one of those packaged services.

pros: There are very few pros, although many of the staff are friendly and approachable.  That is really about it.
cons:
Ridiculously low pay
Management who do not listen to their staff
40 minutes allowance a month for toilet breaks
Almost every email from management ends in the, now infamous, "Or further action will be taken"
Overly punitive management style
Breaks are way too short
The shift pattern ensures that one never gets enough sleep to actually function as a human being.
Boorish management who seem to think that talking loudly somehow earns respect
Endless rule changes which staff usually only find out about once receiving "Performance Improvement Plans" or disciplinaries.
More concerned with reaching meaningless targets such as "How quickly you can get the user off the phone" rather than actually fixing issues
Possibly illegal behaviour designed to make the company look as if it is reaching said targets
A culture of dishonesty
Cronyism inasmuch as one is only likely to have any career development if one went to school with or, otherwise, know management outside of work
A culture of unquestioning obedience where even suggestions which go against management ideas is treated as insubordination
A patronising mentality where staff are treated like school children
Different rules and behavioural standards from department to department
One rule for management and another for staff

free drinks machine

pros: Some co-workers became like a family.
cons: Don't ever work with these guys. The pay is very low. If you are working at NIC-Fujitsu in Lidcombe for Experis, the work environment there is very bad, lots of politics. They employ people as IT Technicians, but make them work in labour jobs doing picking/packing, stock take. Then you have to lift heavy printers, UPS etc all by yourself because Fujitsu doesn't want to spend money and is all the time looking for cost cutting opportunities. Experis will put you into this hell of an environment and keep getting promotions after promotions. They don't listen and don't care about anybody. job_title: Senior Customer Solutions Architect in Manchester, England
pros: Great people in the main, some good opportunities to work on some great projects and places, lots of great potential if the the cons could be addressed.  Somewhere i would return to.
cons: Very old style management, Kept in dark, lack of communication and direction from the top, invisible leadership. lack of focus on career path unless you resigned, vision hidden.  Lack of appetite to move out of comfort zone, too many people been their too long and not moved with the times (dead wood).  Remuneration packages stagnate quickly, pay rises very poor, promotion board very poor.

review_title: I had my doubts at first, BUT
pros: FNC is a really great place these days. The company used to have a very conservative, slow, siloed culture, and remnants of that attitude can still be found in some of the old guard who have been here 15+ years (but not everyone, and on the flip side, this is certainly the kind of company you can retire from!). But FNC is making efforts to change. Execs have open door policies for the most part, and the company is working hard to be more welcoming, open, and agile. My team is friendly and supportive and my managers are 100% supportive of both personal and professional growth. There is a lot of opportunity here, and switching jobs/departments within the company isn't frowned upon. Competitive pay, too!
cons:
- Can still be slow to change in certain situations
- Few (but increasing) number of employees under 30. Very tame environment.
- The medical insurance isn't great

review_title: Good Stepping Stone / Bad Staying Place
job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Richardson, TX
pros: I was fortunate to have a good manager out of Richardson who was mindful of my workload and the scope of my projects, which made it easy to balance my work and home time.
cons: Not all managers care about work/life balance. Communication between divisions and department levels is minimal and causes many issues when trying to implement new processes or improvements. Transferring within the company is almost never done, this is due to preconceived notions about people from certain divisions and poor management communication.

job_title: Account Executive in Santa Clara, CA
pros: My co-workers were great. Frontline sales reps are seasoned veterans and have a lot of experience to share. Being the 800 lb. gorilla in the scanning industry made it easier. Compensation and benefits were good for peripheral market.
cons: It's tough to grow in a mature market. Having over half of the market and trying to gain more is tough. As others have stated before, the political climate is hard to swallow if you're not a part of that inner circle. Strategic direction is not that defined and can change constantly. The culture in the office is very sterile. Workers are afraid of CEO and unfortunately I believe he enjoys that. That negative energy can derail productivity. Still, if it is that bad, then one has a choice to leave or stay.

job_title: Associate Systems Engineer in Wellington, Wellington
pros: None to be completely honest.
cons: They refuse to compensate appropriately.

review_title: Good Work Life balance, Great place for experienced crowd. Not good for freshers.
pros:
Good Work Life Balance - Though policies have changed recently, but still the company is lenient on WFH policies.
Employee satisfaction programs.
Good atmosphere & campus
Easily accessible senior management
Will be rewarded as a good performer
cons:
Lack of focus at Sr. management level.
Business/Project Opportunities come at random. There is no stability on ongoing/long running projects.
If you get stuck up in the wrong project at the wrong time, it would get very hard to escape the situations.
The concept of low bench is in place now and you might be asked to work on a different skillset, if the opportunities are not there on your skillset and this is a mandate, unless you try to convince the Resourcing team that you cannot work. Continuous 3 rejections on projects and you are kicked out.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work, now its unpleasant.
pros: Regular paycheck, nice canteen, buildings look nice and theres the free car parking as well. The security staff are cheerful, as are the cleaners, I get to see a lot more of them than any form of management individual putting in my unpaid overtime every day...
cons: nonexistant or insulting payrises (1% or less) removal of right to work from home on a management whim, expectation that you'll go the extra mile and sacrifice: if you dare ask for a bonus or a payrise you'll be told " you're bonus is you still have a Job" Huge workloads, senior management driving convertible mercedes with an insulting attitude to staff, working late on christmas eve instead of the traditional half day off... shall I go on ?

review_title: I've seen worse...but not by much
pros:
Hours are pretty flexible.  
My boss is awesome but I really don't think he is indicative of others.
cons:
LEADERLESS.  The leadership presence is just a steady stream of emails about who has been hired and what restructuring is occurring. Get off your derriere and talk to people. 
Company is in cost cutting mode, big time. I hear they are suggesting "unpaid leave" to save the company money. Not too impressive for a global company. 
Salaries are low and they never change. 1 or 2% raises annually. 
The company has no HR department. Literally. No one. 
You have to "apply" to be considered for promotion.  No matter how deserving. 
Spineless management. The people just go along with everything and stick up for no one. 
Dismal future. The sales team hasn't brought anything meaningful in for a long time and the one big account they did land is all messed up.

review_title: MSSP - Lot's of opportunities for experience
pros: Work at this MSSP is very demanding for most of the skill sets: server network, application or security. If you want to test your ability to operate in a service provider environment, fast-paced, customer-driven with limited resources, this will work well. It is a fairly young company, with a lot of diversity in the customer base, and a lot of demanding situations to conquer. If you thrive in a challenging environment, check this company out.
cons: The management of the company is bottom-line driven, which means offshoring is a constant, use of contractors to temporarily backfill and slow approvals of requisitions for filling vacancies is a given. There is no real review of services offered by the sales team by the operations teams, so no control of contracted service levels. Communication within the company is very poor, and not well organized.

review_title: Take it if it is your only option
pros:
- Good hiring pay
- Some benefits are good
- A few nice people to work with
- Onsite company gym and cafeteria
- Large company
- CEO is a pleasure to work with.
cons:
There are quite a few cons of working here. 
- Outdated/conservative company culture that reminds me of the movie "Office Space" or like a modern "Mad Men". 
- Lack of coordination and cooperation between departments/companies. Everyone is looking out for themselves and do not work like a team.
- Anti-social office behavior is prized over colloboration
- Poor strategic direction and not gaining revenue
- Top management is rude, gossiping children that do not understand core components of the company. 
- Company culture is not good, even though they are trying to fix it. Top management is like poison for the rest of the company
- Deception of company from the moment of hire.
- Lack of recognition or respect, depending on your position.

review_title: Average but a good starting position
job_title: Incident Manager/Service Control Officer in Wakefield, England
pros: Fujitsu are a good company for taking on people with  limited experience or qualifications. If you're willing to start at the bottom and work your way up this is a good place to start.
cons:
The pay is by par below the market average, the justification for the pay scale at the low roles is you do not need previous experience or qualifications, however as you move up the company you need to evidence everything you do, if you do have the experience and qualifications then you won't be considered for the role (just like most companies) however you would therefore expect as you process the pay would reflect the market average but it falls way short thought the company, putting the previous justification of low pay into question.
This is backed up by the high turnover of staff as people come in to the company and then leave for much more money once experience is gained.

review_title: Can Fujitsu North America Turn Around?
pros: Fujitsu as a whole is a great company to work for as their R&D is excellent.  Their servers and laptops are some of the best engineered products in the market with great durability.
cons: In my opinion, Fujitsu North America is a dying organization that cannot meet their financial commitment back to Japan.  Executives management's’ primary tool is to cut head count which takes down moral, impacts customer service and inhibits  Fujitsu North America’s chance to recover from negative returns and start growing again.  Current executive management in the services division do not understand the consulting business or how to grow it.  Consequently, Fujitsu America’s services portfolio has significantly diminished as their top talent has fled to better organizations.

review_title: Good company to gather valuable management experience as it matures
pros: On the whole - all the people with whom I work closely are really 'likeable', professional & supportive. The working culture is very good in terms of consultant & management knowledge-sharing & collaboration, and organizational transparency. Plus everyone I have encountered are very helpful & non-competitive (and I have definitely seen the other extreme in other companies I've worked for). Also, there are a lot of choices for benefits offered (use a newer consumer driven health plan - Lumenos - through Blue Cross Blue Shield, which is quite comprehensive & cost effective).
cons: Structure is lacking - company has been transitioning constantly & is not very well organized. I have been a part of several of these major organizational changes since I joined 2.5 years ago: (1) the acquisition of 3 smaller consulting companies; (2) company downsizing (bench surplus); (3) replacing poor top management; (4) employee retention issues; (5) and soon to be merging with its sister company - Fujitsu Computer Systems.

pros: Decent benefits, some really fine and skillful people.  Ability for most to telework.  Really long hours are rare.  Some newer managers are driving change.
cons: While some managers are working hard to drive change, other managers are not competent for their positions and they set their direct reports up for failure.  Good ol' boy network exists and isn't going anywhere.  You'll need to know who to schmooze and be able to promote yourself at every juncture.  Blame gets tossed around when failures occur.  Don't say anything that you don't want repeated.
