review_title: Focus on being the cheapest, not being the best
pros:
- If you get the right manager, can be a good place to gain experience and industry knowledge.
- Plenty of room to move, to a certain point.
- Exposure to most industry standards.
cons:
- Real focus on being the cheapest and chasing every possible deal.
- Too much middle management. Everyone is a 'director' or 'general manager'.
- Not enough done in the employee benefits space. A slight discount off a monthly gym membership that you can get cheaper elsewhere anyway is not a benefit.
- Felt as though HR were the custodians of the company and never actually helped the employees. People were worked into the ground and no proactive management of this was made by HR or anyone else.
- A real culture of '2-out 1-in' when it comes to staff procurement.
- Probably the worst salaries you will find in the industry.

review_title: Most of the time, it's like a family
job_title: Senior Customer Solutions Architect in London, England
pros: Varied work, flexible locations, excellent people, flexible benefits, good pension. I've worked at ICL/Fujitsu  for over 15 years. I've had the opportunity to choose most of my assignments, and have generally received good support to deliver successful solutions. I think I receive fair remuneration. I particularly like the stars programme, where you can recommend a peer for an award or remuneration, or just a big thank you.
cons:
Sometimes forced to use old technology for too long.  No consistent mobile strategy. Examples - Most of the world are embracing IOS and android phones, whereas we tend to go for the cheapest, e.g. Windows. We don't embrace Open Source enough. We need more products in our portfolio.
 There are a few people who still only do the minimum or worse, try and harm the company.

pros: The people are excellent.  Many folks have been at Fujitsu for a long time.  Work-life balance is good and encouraged.  Benefits are ok.  Large Tier 1 customers keep the machine turning.  Backed by one of the world's largest Information Communication Technology companies out of Japan, Fujitsu Limited.
cons: Fujitsu sustains its reputation on not being first to market but highest in quality.  But not being first to market and having a narrowing solution set is taking its toll on market share.  The focus has been on flat to declining technology market segments.  Five or six years ago there was a major shift in the industry that Fujitsu missed out on.  Now there is another and it remains to be seen if Fujitsu can execute on its plans for this latest shift.  Fujitsu understands the changing market place and has good strategies to back it up.  Strategy has not been an issue.  Execution of strategy remains a challenge.

review_title: Good Place to Work if You Like Long Days
job_title: Network and Computer Systems Administrator in Dallas, TX
pros: The pay is good and benefits are decent.
cons: As in many organizations, the sales department is king. Promises made by sales filters down to service implementers and support staff without concern to actually service the customer.  Many teams are understaffed and everything is "high priority." Support staff is left to clean up the mess from poorly defined sales contracts where little or no planning was conducted beforehand. This leads to very long work weeks and weekend work. Plan on working 50-75 hour weeks if you are in a support role.

pros: World wide work hence can chance to interact with the world , abroad visits, Working on latest technology , technology awareness, Most of the development projects are under proof of concepts and working on those projects or rather I say you can contribute to companies growth while working on another billable projects.
cons: Managment is not cooperative , Although you get heired for some technology but it's not true that you will  get to work in the same. If you are a developer and if the company doesn't have development project then you may be asked to work on support or any different technology. If you get single escalation or few  then salary hike will be up to the mark .  Internal politics is another concerns.  Questions may get raised on your work although you are working honestly and hence you always have to create proofs of your work.

pros: I can think of none.
cons: Fujitsu North American and specifically the BAS unit is a leader free business unit that is ruled by 1990's management and solutions. The company espouses their great insight into digital transformation solutions for the marketplace yet they stifle innovation and modernization throughout the internal workforce. A good old boys club of inept sr. management that rewards the wrong behaviors and people for being mediocre and for following orders. Great place to work if you seek domineering leaders, limited advancement and growth opportunities and an atmosphere of servitude amongst the rank and file. Leaders need not apply nor seek hire as the first new thought or great idea will forever brand as nonconformist with an exit strategy in the future. A terrible place to work, especially with the current digital age transformations generating so much excitement. Don't join fujitsu if you want progress but if you like stagnation, sign up now, they need more "yes" people to blindly follow orders.

review_title: Great people at the work end, but a determination to make everything difficult by the management
job_title: Customer Solutions Architect in Manchester, England
pros:
Some great staff in technical roles can make delivery easy. A good flexibility to working from home although this is often an informal agreement. Work is very varied and I'm pretty much in control of my own workload and delivery of it.
I've had some good mid-level managers who have genuinely seemed to care about how I was doing (as a person as well as at work)
cons:
Top level management and processes seem designed to make implementation of new technologies as painful as possible.
Company seems to be very focused on London and SE England, if your in one of the northern offices, you can feel out on a limb.
Appraisal system seems designed to make proving your doing valuable and well respected work difficult, if it doesn't fit into a nice little package.

pros: Most of the lower level employees were great to work with and are great people in general.
cons: The micromanagement approach and ruling with an iron fist approach is not a good way to motivate your employees nor will it bring the best out them. It does the exact opposite. While I was there, long term as well as employees who haven't been there a whole year were leaving either because they found better opportunities elsewhere or they needed to distance themselves from the constant negativity and demoralizing effects it had on them. I was one of those that left and I do not regret it.

pros:
Great work-life balance for someone at my level, not so sure for others up the chain. Your experience here is dependent on your manager. My manager has been autonomous, supportive and understanding of my personal life and my career at Fujitsu, but I have known a handful of individuals to leave due to poor micromanaging management. 
I have amazing flexibility, and help when I reach out. The physical office isn't a bustling environment, but the people you need are usually available regardless.
cons: Low morale with the loss of business over the last few years and layoffs. Fujitsu is working to build itself back up again, and has improved over the last year. It is tough to motivate employees that have been working here for a long time, to shift to the next level.

review_title: Fujitsu Networks Communications(FNC) India as a work place
pros: Good knowledge experience, methodical way of working, process oriented, you get to work on most recent technologies, no maintainance work, Salary at par with Market
cons:
FNC is still not a legal entity in India. You will be employed under Fujitsu Consulting India Ltd (FCIL) which is a services company. Policy framework belongs to FCIL which follows services policy framework and not product company framework. Hence policies are far from satisfactory. 

People employed by FNC in India needs to work with their outsourcing vendors wipro and Aricent. FNC India does not have its own office. At the moment they are sitting in Wipro Campus. There are plans though to come out of Wipro campus.  

As of now they plan to operate from Chennai only.

Overall FNC India is still a work in Progress. But overall a good to have professional experience

pros:
Flexible 
Work and life balance
cons:
People I worked with were all great people and supportive and helpful and some are very skillful and knowledgeable.
The problem is the managements. 
Some of their KPI is to think how to reduce commissions sales people get. They set many rules that sales people have to follow so it consumes so much time  and sales people cannot focus on hunting for new opportunities.
No flexibility on the process. New small rules  can be created without  officially announced and its not helping but only give sales people more work to do. Yet managements push sales people to sell more and hit target. 
Process just to book in the order is so tedious and sales cannot focus on hunting new opportunities. Need to spend so much time for paperwork and ask around all department for approval. 

Honestly I didn’t feel any sense of appreciation from management when I leave even they can see my contribution.
I will not recommend to join the company.

review_title: Good to get experience then get out
pros: Potential for good salary; good chance for easy promotion if you love playing corporate politics; relatively easy to get promoted into position without relevant skills or experience. Good marketing and strong graduate hiring program.  Management have good understanding of current technology trends.
cons: Micro managing Australian CEO with a history of poor results but still allowed to run company into the ground after many years; Japanese senior management allow the rot to continue. Huge influx of inexperienced graduates lack any decent mentorship within the company, it is like “blind leading the blind”; experienced people leaving in droves, increases pressure on those left behind. Management keen to respond to glass door online reviews but missing in action when providing feedback internally. Offshoring more and more roles, but most are very low quality offshore teams, continually creating issues that need locals to fix up. Low morale. Depressing work place. Actual delivery capabilities don’t match all the marketing hype. Unable to transform understanding of technology trends into real world applications and successful implementations that go beyond POCs. Does not practice what it preaches - internal IT environment not remotely close to solutions recommended for customers.

review_title: Management intent on destroying what little morale remains
pros: A fantastic bunch of colleagues with excellent skills you would be hard pushed to replace, unfortunately they are under valued and taken for granted by management, interesting and varied job which is challenging and satisfying.
cons: No promotion prospects, poor/non existent salary reviews. Staff induced into completing a performance review process which gives the company a tick in the box for investment in people and nothing else. There is no performance related pay, the latest scam is to say the pay pot has to be used to sort out pay anomalies for those who are 25% below the median (who created the problem in the first place?). Your email inbox is inundated with 'red top' emails citing which management pleb has been promoted or the team that got re-organised 3 months ago is changing its name again.

review_title: Mostly good, some great, still ripe for improvement
pros: Some good teams and individuals, some good management. Usually hard work is rewarded. Opportunities from the big brand, its technologies and CSR commitment. Some leadership that realises we have to change.
cons: Regional leadership trying to translate global strategy; some dreadful outdated internal IT portals from the ICL era; some dreadful new internal IT that is a UX nightmare. Mind numbing browser based training for all. Work here and spend a lot of time worrying that agile startups will take it away from you. Or that similar large companies will find a more effective approach. And everything they say about ICL is true.

review_title: A place to learn then move on
pros:
The assignments given to employees of Fujitsu are often challenging, one-of-a-kind scenarios that force you to think outside the box and grow significantly.
The company has a number of international branches with various specialties
cons:
The various branches operate independently of one another and doesn't necessarily encourage cross training of resources
Some managers seem to encourage favoritism of employees. As a result, there are many cases of unqualified employees being promoted or given awards. 
Compensation is not competitive
There are too many instances where employees are forced to work extremely long hours and suffer from burnout or exhaustion because management does not hire the right number of resources to complete the various assignments

review_title: Review for Fujitsu Ten Solutions Philippines, Inc.
pros:
- Training provided if there is a need for it
- Rice and Transportation allowance
- They promote camaraderie (sports fest, team building, parties)
- Overseas training / Overseas employment / Overseas deployment (selected employees)
- Nihongo classes. Pass the Japanese internal exam and you get a cash incentive monthly.
- Medical reimbursements (limited)
cons:
- You won't know your salary and won't be able to review the contract until the orientation is over. It was a disappointing starting salary and it was hard to decline the contract after spending a whole day with the people from HR.
- Performance appraisal was kind of subjective. It was hard to earn a high to perfect grade because they keep changing the criteria for each key area evaluation (depends on the department). And there is no way to rate your superior. (I don't know if they updated this at the moment)
- Training has a 2-year bond.
- flexi time is only from 7:30-8:30. Come in beyond 8:31 and you're considered late.
- No health card

pros: Great people. Mostly talented with high skills. Global company. Head office doing some really cool stuff via R&D etc
cons:
Exec management have got no idea as to what make a good services company. They are focussed on cutting cost rather than improving the service they provide to their current customers The company is focussed on cutting internal costs as opposed to optimising their services.
Head office is Japan focussed - which is OK while that's where the majority of revenue comes from - however why can't Australia get access to the tech that the other regions have access to?

pros:
Lots of locations and customers to work with in the UK
Very service based and geared around the latest ITSM methodologies.
cons: I worked for Fujitsu for 13 years. In that time,  I was left working at home, or on some customer sites, alone, without management guidance or even - in one case - any contact for months, Training was limited as there was often no budget. Difficult customer accounts meant higher levels of stress, and employees are then whipped faster to appease the customer. I was also made to work from home after an accident, unable to even walk, because there was nobody else to do the work and they depended solely upon me. If you are a very loyal, enthusiastic and persistent team player, or you can wine and dine the right people, then you might get into a good position with a good wage. Otherwise, don't expect much in the way of salary or support.

review_title: Supportive organisation who develop people well - weak go-to-market execution
pros:
- Supportive people with "can do" attitude
- Good EMEIA coverage, which is developing as a strategic concern
- Portfolio based regional P&L structure gives autonomy to regions
- Strong client base
- Great organisation to develop your career and get cross-sector experience
cons:
- Weak strategy, complicated through a portfolio that is too large and a go-to-market (sectors and countries) that are too large. 
- Japan HQ do not understand western markets and complicate working environment
- Huge focus on reorganisation to solve the companies problems
- Over-complicated company operating model
- Weak on offshore and limited IP, which will ultimately lead to revenue decline unless FJ embraces a major global aquisition

pros:
- Kind and supportive colleagues across the company. Collaboration is valued and people are happy to help.
- Lots of experience and expertise in the company.
- Good entry level salary at graduate level.
- In a lot of roles, there is the opportunity to work remotely.
- Very supportive of people with families, good maternity/paternity leave though no personal experience of this.
- Really liked the focus on CSR and supporting charity partners - the company is genuinely committed to this.
cons:
- Processes can be extremely slow, frustrating for us and client.
- Old boys club mentality is prevalent and off putting.
- Being told to do things "because we have to" even if it doesn't deliver value to us or the client, too much red tape.
- Graduate programme experience varies massively depending on where you are placed - it is disingenuous for the company to imply it is a level playing field.
- Can feel like a dinosaur - seems to be behind on major tech developments.

review_title: Highly Unprofessional and No Employee friendly
pros:
I joined this organization as a Full Time lateral Managing Solution Architect in Dearborn MI, I was told that this is a permanent position and  it will not be changed. 
The ground reality is that they are running a big Show with NO EXPERIENCE in that stream. They are doing a very big project but they are not expertise in it.
cons:
Management is monotonous.
They do not listen for employees.
Solution they are selling to customer is questionable as they are not Capability Matured in it like Wipro, TCS or any other integration company.
Management is based in UK and they are highly racist. 
They have dummy HR processes like PIR or etc, which they use to fire a candidate with a very no cause. 
Be very much cautious in communication with management as they even read read word by word and they fire even on SPELLINGS and GRAMMATICAL MISTAKES. 

No Industry experience in running Big projects.
Not a Public listed reputed company.
They don't bother their reputation as they are not a public entity.
Simply a WASTE of TIME and CAREER.

review_title: a place to take things easy but prepared to  suffer the wrath of the mediocre
pros: Quite laid back with work/life balance clearly understood.
cons: in the csa community the mediocre truly rule.  If you want to continue to be a techie then this may not be the place for you with no praise for doing something clever/smart of inventive but instead top marks awarded for doing a save-as on someone else's design or filling in timesheets on time.  The tech leads seem be scared of anyone with energy and a drive to get things moving which is a real as some of the staff are very talented.

pros: Flexible, ok type work environment, unlike other MNC's did not see any layoff even if you are on bench for long time,Brand name, attractive salary package for lateral hiring
cons: went from  bad to worse when I  joined...Full of politics ,incompetent mid level managers, not much projects as per database side, even getting a project of 1-2 FT resource is a great achievement for them..can you believe this. ??.....lucky if you get project matching your skill or else they may push you to some other project which is not part of your skillset..good only for boot lickers...From 3000 employess..it has reduced to 2100..in 3 years....Lot of management changes both in India GDC and in international business....very few onsites...only for 2-3 weeks...no career growth

review_title: Overpoweringly bureaucratic and out of touch with their staff.
pros: Good technical staff, good physical working environments, customer-focused, training and development is improving (albeit slowly - not enough & not often enough), people are generally very decent.
cons:
Very little daily variety despite a wide skill-set amongst many employees.

Overbearing bureaucracy and a patronising approach to staff relations. Middle managers with no technical competence managing experienced technical staff in a very claustrophobic way which stifles autonomy and freedom of expression.

Attempts to improve "enablement and engagement" have been embarrassing. Problems are identified then simply wrapped up in a new and cringeworthy acronym or abbreviation then force-fed to all staff via email (or "corporate communications"). Middle managers love these and get all excited about them, as if we didn't have enough normal work to do we now have to embrace things like "comm cells" and "sense and respond" for crying out loud. This is all very well but there simply isn't the time!

pros:
Working at FNC has been a great experience. The culture is changing and there is more transparency in the company then when I began. There is a lot of opportunity currently to move up and take on more responsibilities. I think that Senior Management has done a great job of transforming the culture. 

The work/life balance at FNC is excellent. It appears to be that way in most departments from the people that I talk to.
cons: The business is currently stagnant. The future of the company  and their profits is relying on new ventures in solutions and services. The future of the company isn't 100% certain. This really isn't too much of "con" because this type of risk is what it will take to break out of the stagnation.

review_title: Well Balanced Company Trying to Make a Difference
pros: FNC has a solid talent base with a good balance of new and old ideas.  The company is trying very hard to improve its culture and foster innovation.  Old barriers of outdated processes and silos are slowly being broken down.  Its an exciting time at the company and many new projects and next generation products are being developed.
cons: The company is still struggling with changing old habits.  Management needs some fresh blood and some organizational decisions need to be re-evaluated (similar to many other companies).  Its difficult to move up in the organization and opportunities for climbing the ladder are few.  The cafeteria food needs improvement.

pros:
Some genuinely great people that want to make a difference but are seldom listened to.

A great place to work if your face fits with the 'club'
cons:
Change on change, and knee jerk reaction when the latest change doesn't bear fruit immediately. 
Staff moral is at an all time low yet shockingly incompetent mid and senior management continue to  abdicate responsibility, steering the company toward a cliff edge.

pros:
in general it is a well established company with creative and professional people in several areas which is very useful to build and develop your skills

you will have the opportunity to work in interesting projects and with large scale customers

benefits are vary depend on the country and the department

personal development depends on the customer need, but generally fujitsu has several partnerships with other vendors which can provide special trainings
cons:
with such large scale company it's hard to deliver your voice or ideas to higher management

You don't feel of it as a one company when it comes to deal or cooperate with teams in another country, fujitsu in each country has it's own rules and system

depend on the country and the department, some may have unclear vision and lack of honesty with their employees

in some countries you will find teams separated by technology which will lock your career to a specific technology/area only and it's hard to get out of it

review_title: Stick a Fork in it.  It's Done.
pros: Some people are very bright and you can learn new things from them.  Company provides training and courses that can expand your knowledge.
cons:
Low employee morale caused by the constant threat of surprise layoffs.  One day they give you 10-year achievement award, the next day you clean your desk.  I literally witnessed such situation here.  
Promotions are unheard of.  The same goes for the raises.  They pay low, and don't give reasonable COLA increases, constant emergency "pay freezes."
I had an extremely rude and unprofessional supervisor with the history of anger and hostility toward subordinates and coworkers.  I went to complain to his boss.  The boss told me "well, you know, that's how he is."  Are you kidding me?  The company knows about his unacceptable behavior, but would not do anything to correct it!  Unbelievable!  After I quit I found out that he's a part of the good old boys club so he's pretty much untouchable.  This is worse than nepotism!

review_title: Not a bad company, just bad management
pros:
Good work/life balance
Onsite cafeteria and gym
Good pay and benefits
A lot of smart and talented people there
cons: Decisions take way too long. Management tends to be in a constant "paralysis by analysis". Every decision has to be cleared with Japan and they are extremely risk adverse and there are often conflicts of interest on business priorities. Most of all, communication among the ranks and direction to the works is often unclear and muddled. Often what is said in the town halls isn't really what is going on behind closed doors and the vision of the company is described in platitudes instead of real concrete plans.

pros:
- Local team and people are great
- Good work culture
- Interesting work, changes often
- Training when required and asked for
- Defence Clearance sponsor
cons:
- Corporate management are useless, no idea about industry trends or how to disrupt the market (all are old sales people, no young tech people)
- Always one step behind, slow to change and innovate
- Australian CEO appears to be running the local company into the ground, more concerned with cost cutting and margins than investing in the right people and technology
- Employee benefits are basically non-existent

pros: Although my role is client facing but I can work remotely. No need to face client everyday. Slow paced and easy work environment.
cons:
At Fujitsu, we mostly work on traditional IT. Lack of vision and strategy are visible company wide. As a solution architect, it is very frustrating to see this company does not want to engage in high tech opportunities. This company only participate in low level IT contract and engagement i.e. help desk and desktop support. Sometimes it's frustrating to see why Fujitsu needs solution architect at workplace when they participate in low level contract. 

Although Fujitsu manufactured K-computer but Fujitsu does not have any commitment to innovation. In the last few years innovation mostly down to zero level. 

As far as architecture and project management concern, there is no real architecture team to architect any infrastructure. There is no project to manage or govern although there are senior management in project management.  
Senior management is reluctant to undertake any project activities. It is probably the worse senior management I ever work with.

pros:
Friendly work environment
Relaxed depending on contract
Opportunities for the lucky ones
Great for getting your foot in the IT industry
cons:
Sometimes management are unable to make decisions and issues are left in limbo. 

Fujitsu is a very process heavy company and this can cause a great deal of issues. If a user is experiencing a problem, rather than straight up fixing an issue if there is very little to no impact the company will choose to insist on following process causing a delay to the user.

Pay is terrible compared to other companies. They do not offer a competitive salary.

job_title: Senior Network Engineer in Warrington, England
pros:
Home working
Benefits
Great career progression for managers
The people who actually do the front line work.
cons:
Process and admin tasks get in the way of doing your job.
Career development opportunities rare
Lack of investment in the right people
Top heavy with management
Too many barriers to productivity
Constant threat of redundancy
The manner in which they are conducting the most recent cull in staff is an utterly disgrace... uncertainty for those involved and never knowing for weeks at a time if you are going to be axed or not. All done by email or telecast... no personal intervention which is cowardly and unprofessional. Loyalty and dedication count for nothing... ifollow your face fits and you can trot out a few clichés and buzz words you'll go far.

pros:
Majority of the people I have worked with at Fujitsu are really understanding and willing to help and there is often a team environment. 
Large company so always opportunity to move internally. 
Pension scheme very good.
cons:
Awful communication from management, redundancy programmes every few years which are dealt with appallingly by management with no real clue of what the desired outcome should be, with the main focus to cut costs wherever possible. 
Senior Management are disconnected and are not trustworthy, 
Internal moves do not increase salary, only experience.
Systems in use by the company are not fit for purpose, there are too many systems in place too, though this has improved over the past couple of years.

pros: Flexible working, if your old and have outdated skills you can probably exist here for a very very long time as seems the case with half the work force.
cons: Clueless management completely out of touch with reality of customer,  leadership team is more like an old boys club, bangs on about diversity to tick the right boxes but totally out of touch. Inappropriate jokes etc already cost one senior their job. Painfully slow to react to opportunities and incredibly high turn over of sales staff and client execs. Still living of the major service contracts of yester year and the associated churn, no sight of real innovation or winning technology.

review_title: It is what you make of it
pros: The graduate programme features excellent training for soft skills, and the graduate community as a whole is well looked after with opportunities to get involved in numerous activities outside of your role.
cons: Although there are opportunities to get involved outside of your role, often it's the day job that is the shortcoming of this scheme. Some graduates have been underwhelmed with the roles they were assigned, and although there is the flexibility to rotate (although this is very much down to the individual to initiate), often this doesn't make up for the lack of fulfilling work. I also get the feeling this company doesn't operate as a meritocracy, but instead favours the employees who can shout the loudest.

review_title: Enjoyable but low pay and no prospects
pros: Worked in a good team, doing a job I enjoyed, Banter, good place as a step up into another career at a higher paying company such as HP, MS, CGI etc
cons: No training was provided, Overtime took far to long and to much efford to get paid, No payrises or bonus, rubbish shift cycle, staff shortages and staff overworked and under paid. Higher management dont listen to your views and nobody took an interest in trying to change things. Despite several attempts to move to another role internally these were all blocked or covered up with promises of training which never happened.

pros: Multicultural environment is well established.
cons:
People who are promoted on a new role they dont actually got promoted in the HR system for a significant amount of time.  Therefore, they are not paid fairly for the role they perform but actually paid with monthly allowance for extra responsibilities instead of a proper yearly salary. The most popular excuse on this is that the role is in developing or acting phase etc. Developing roles cannot last forever so company can pay allowances to staff and not the appropriate salary. 

Either the company is happy with employees' progress in the first 3 months or so, there is no ''probation'' period that lasts a year. 

Poor Salaries comparing to other IT companies for similar roles 
Poor management- no motivation - progress 
Low level of literacy and generally low level of qualifications

pros: Though there were few positives working at FCPA, there are wonderful employees there, with good intentions. FCPA has a gracious holiday schedule, along with a shutdown during Christmas. It is a solid place to learn a few skills, and apply them elsewhere, since there is no structure for growth.
cons: There were two large negatives at FCPA. Japan often pushed down initiatives with little regard or basic understanding of what that means for the workforce. There is a complete and total disconnect of what is happening not only within the office, but within the market. The other is the complete lack of management. The CEO is involved in all decisions because there is no trust of management and staff. Managers and other executives are only expected to follow orders regardless of the impact on the workforce or company. It is a culture of suspicion, and gossip.

review_title: Fujitsu Manila GDC is one of the worst employers I've worked for.
pros: The only positive point I can think of - I no longer work with them.
cons:
Employee services - abysmal. All of HR from the R&F up to their management ignore the employees. They are only good when recruiting you but once they get you to accept the job offer you're on your own.
Payroll - you get deductions without any explanation. Don't bother asking for an explanation because they will ignore you.
Helpdesk - one of the worst. It takes weeks before they respond and tickets frequently get closed without any resolution. If they offer a solution to your technical problem, ignore it because they have no idea how to solve the problem.
Managers & team leaders - useless. They do nothing but walk around asking people - `everything okay?' - but unable to do anything when you have issues.
Performance evaluation system - an absolute joke. Don't ask your team leaders to explain the PE system to you because, very likely, they don't know. Pay increases - not even enough to cover inflation.

review_title: Glad I joined, good products and people, the "IBM" of Japan!
pros: Old friends, new friends, very high quality products.  The pay was good, and management was good to work with.  Treated very well when I left. At times, our products were leading the industry, and in general, customers were quite satisfied.  A little history; if I'm not mistaken, Fujitsu was the primary builder of the old Amdahl computer, way back when, (mainframe), and it was a very impressive and widely  respected computer system in its day.
cons: Sometimes lagging with new models, and since design engineers were in Japan, plus of course some lingering "trust" issues, you didn't always get a crisp answer quickly. For me, it was hard that I couldn't go see, or just pick up the phone and talk to anybody I wanted to, especially those in key positions.  What I mean is most were of course, in Japan.

review_title: Good place for the right person
pros: Global player in the IT services market, with opportunities to work almost anywhere in the world. Industrial partnerships, and potential for involvement in innovative solutions. Colleagues who are honest, genuine, and talented.
cons: Upper management is hopelessly out of touch with the people on the front lines. They talk a good game about how their employees are their most important assets - but they do not put their money or their actions where their mouths are. Resource managers are less concerned with the welfare of their charges (the consultants) than with their own best interests, which frequently are in conflict with the best interests of the consultants they are placing.

review_title: Stagnant company, future outlook is cloudy.
pros:
Good company to join for young people with no job experience. Will be able to learn about business while working.

No layoffs in Japan, as you get older salary will increase unrelated to performance.

People are nice.

Good company if you want to under perform and but still do not get laid off.
cons:
Work efficiency is horrible. Employees has low base pay so they perform unnecessary over times.
Very low salary compare to the market. Since there's no layoffs, some people does not contribute to the company but still get paid higher than the high performer since they are older.

The senior management tells their employees one thing, but their action is completely opposite.

Seniors decides everything. Not open to new ideas. Their reason is, because we been doing this process for years.

job_title: Human Resources Advisor in London, England
pros:
Very good work life balance - less pressurised than the larger American IT firms
Relatively informal structure - colleagues at all levels (bar the very top) are approachable
Good effort being made to become a more inclusive employer
cons:
Huge inequality in pay and benefits - expect to find someone doing the same job as you earning twice as much, because they've been here 20 years
Indecisiveness - every decision is subject to a 17 stage, 3 month review by which time the moment has passed
Confrontational, bipolar executive team who are above any policy we have on bullying and harassment
Opportunities seemingly limited to graduates or the Old Boy's Club
No sincerity in working with employee bodies

review_title: Not at Top Tier Level Yet
job_title: Principal Project Manager in Irvine, CA
pros:
- Compensation and benefits are good
- Trying to become bigger and better
- They leave you alone with your clients as long as you're billable
cons:
- They're trying to make Fujtisu Consulting into an IBM Global Services and other big consulting firm, but they are far from it.  I used to work at IBM Global Services and its night and day difference.  
- Not a long of communications between management, consultants, and peers
- Not a lot of processes or methodologies, but they're trying
- Focused is mostly in IT consulting, esp. in SAP, Oracle and ERP consulting.  So if you're into ecommerce, web, strategy, business process, then you're the few
- Not a sharing / collaborative culture
- Don't have the resources for training and equipment like IBM and other big consulting firms

review_title: My overall experience with the company was a good one.
job_title: Customer Service Engineer in Savannah, GA
pros: The company offers plenty of training and you will learn a lot in the field as it relates to hands on troubleshooting hardware and software issues.
cons: Working in remote locations (In the field) where there are only few technicians or you the only technician can be challenging, because you may get a calls to distant locations several times a day when covering for other technicians when they are off on leave, this can result in calls for service being back up, while trying meet SLA's requirements.  This would cause your work days to become very long because of the traveling back and forth.  At some point time this can wear you out.

review_title: Recent rightsizing didn't go far enough
pros: FNC completed the last round of layoffs that were announced a couple of months ago. One goal was to reduce the number of layers of management. The new organization  does look leaner, and departments were shuffled and new ones created to reflect the goals going forward. Kudos for that.
cons: Most of the people let go were deadwood, with a few notable exceptions. But those remaining have been here for years and will continue the same old same old attitude that has gotten FNC to the silo'd, turf protecting company that it is today. We will slug it out and keep on going but we can do much better.

pros: The products and services offered globally are leading edge. The front line consultants are passionate experts.
cons:
The company senior management level. Not universally, but for a large component are not people focued managers nor are they interested in new operating model. The management structure remains stuck in a model from the 1990s. 
The worst offender is the BAS group where the leadership is solely focused on numbers. The predictable effect of this has been that their revenue has dropped 3 years in a row...
I remain here solely to protect my team from negative management pressure.

job_title: Regional Sales Director in Boston, MA
pros: Great 14 year run.  The Fujitsu name alone got you appointments.  Some of my best friends today are former Fujitsu colleagues.  We were the company with products everyone wanted.
cons: Went through 4 CEO's and at least as many Sales VP's in my tenure.  Fujitsu got complacent, lost it's product quality and they seem to have forgot to focus on the customer needs.  Most of the solid people have left the company.  Hopefully with the current sales management, Fujitsu can rekindle that spark that made them terrific.  They appear to be headed in the right direction now with the present sales mindset.  I wish them all the very best.

review_title: Small/Medium Business feel in a division of a Global 500 company.
pros: Positive atmosphere with very little politics, games or drama. Management and employees exposed to a larger scope of responsibility because of lean staffing practices. Able to quickly jump on new opportunities with the stable backing of our global parent. Renewed focus on bringing in quality new grad talent contributing to a more vibrant work atmosphere
cons: Because it is a great place to work there is not very much turnover, but those with talent and ambition will find a place for advancement. Cyclical nature of North American telecom market results in periodic budget and hiring freezes (not generally layoffs since the dot com bubble) followed by periods of rapid growth.

review_title: Risk averse, non-competitive, tied to two major customers, lnexperienced leadership
pros: Good pay, family friendly.  By and large the people I worked with good people.
cons: Incestuous corporate culture.  Everything you say, do, buy and sell must be with other Fujitsu companies.  Clueless or gutless on how to run a business in America.  Extremely cowardly leadership interested only in self preservation and image.  I was with the company for close to two decades and now that I'm out it's glaringly apparent how bad the leadership was in this company.

pros: Made some really nice friends
cons: Worked for fj for over 10 years. Your supposed to get a laptop to cover support, I had to get my boss a cheap mobile phone in order to get my laptop to provide support as a deal. Everything was much a case of deals with the boys to get anything. I was promised a payrise to transfer roles which then never happened. Didn't have an appraisal for years, found out manager was doing them without  me . you have to move roles to get pay rises.current manager is clueless, completely ignores reports of bullying or any wrong doing. I have been offered roles with all Fujitsu's competitors, so will leave.

review_title: ***EVERYTHING is a MESS - VERY VERY POOR MANAGEMENT***
pros: Salary Schedule Nothing more nothing less
cons: Everything is a mess. Incompetent Management who are promoted due to politics. They tell you they have training but doesn't really exist. They don't value employees and they only focus on numbers. Leaves are literally controlled depending on the Sick leave that the team have used and this doesn't apply to everyone on the company except my group. Workload is very high you work on the project while you are on the operations and if ever you cant deliver or meet the expectation of the customer your manager will blame you. Also your manager commit to customer even if he/she doesn't now how to do it so it is pain in your end while the credit goes to your boss. The facilities Sucks, doesn't have tissue paper and the comport rooms are very dirty. Very Very very small pantry for a company. The place is like HELL so if you don't want to have a LIFE then apply on this company.

review_title: Nice coworkers handled by bad management
job_title: Sales Lead in Lisbon, Lisbon District
pros: The team at the Fujitsu GDC  was divers and I had really nice colleagues. Also, the location of the Fujitsu office in Lisbon is nice.
cons: The managers of the sales team do not have any management experiences. They are not open to feedback and do not know how to treat their staff.  It feels like you would be monitored the whole time and they do not trust you (do not employ people that you do not trust).  Furthermore, the workload is not divided appropriately. Some people did not have work for a couple of months, others did not have time for their lunch break.

review_title: Opportunity here, but not for everyone
pros:
Very flexible work options, many WFH or remotely (even in non-Fujitsu cities).
Still some dedicated teams
Possible to move up quickly due to high turnover
cons:
Management is very uneven (some stars, many duds)
Sales pipeline is weak
Overall strategy is probably flawed (taking on outsourced datacenters and IT depts)
HR is terrible (to be fair, company doesn't invest in HR)
General malaise--company doesn't appear to invest in anything or anyone, this causes:
Lack of engagement--so some teams/people are impossible to work with

review_title: Very good work experience in a big international firm
pros: They have a supportive attitude toward employees and it is a good experience working for Fujitsu. Very good work-life balance due to very flexible working hours. They are one of the major players in the IT Industry still offering both a wide range of products and services. Good opportunity to gain experience in both of these fields in very competitive markets. The company is becoming increasingly international which also reflects on the day to day business (cooperation with employees from different countries and cultures).
cons: The company is big and tends to be bureaucratic, more risk averse and rules based with less freedom to divert from rules.

pros: Opportunity for rapid growth if you can take the pressure. A few outstanding leaders and departments can help you advance your IT career if you are in the right one. Decent, but not  great benefits.  Company core values, if followed, provide a sound and healthy company work environment.
cons: Unnecessary stress caused by disorganization and micromanagement. Short term and band-aid fixes abound in most all of the departments. Long term personnel more concerned with maintaining the status quo than improving their departments. Mini empires within the same building.  Cronyism abounds. Too many bosses in too many time zones who were not on the same page create a fluid and often conflicting set of priorities. Top down feedback only. pros: Good Wages, Good Overtime (even though they expect it too often and too long)
cons:
NO !!! Work life balance at all
Expected to work long hours and then get up and be back in the office early the next day, while at the same time trying to study and do up skilling tasks at home
Pay if that good it seems like Golden Handcuffs to keep you there as a pay cut is needed to leave
If expensive training is undertaken then some manager charge you back for the training if you leave within 2 years
No career opportunities or progression as "they cant be seen to be promoting or giving pay rises while redundancy talks are on going in the company", but then higher grade jobs are advertised online.

review_title: FNC Learning to be more than a box vendor
pros:
FNC is very technically strong in the areas they focus which is Layer 0 & 1. 
High quality personal
Focused on the customer
Ability to learn new customer requirements
cons: The biggest issue is the same issue you would hear at any large manufacturing company today. Not moving quickly enough to adapt to changes, politics are thick and get in the way of doing the right thing at times. But the biggest issue outside the normal stuff is they are trying to become more than they were in the past but they are using many of the same people. I think this is a failed model.

review_title: Highly politicized, you can still find good friends if you look really hard.
pros: Hardworking people. If you like routine and stable job without worrying about your wages, this is the place for you. Whether you perform or not, there is very little difference to whatever outcome.
cons: Managers were hired base on relationships, not qualifications. You can expect ground-level people to get way below market wages. Crony managers are well over-paid but channel all their work to the ground-level and non-crony people. Meeting discussions consist of blame-elements instead of solutions. Management preaches about how much they care about the team. Actions are total opposite. There is no clear career path to follow. There is not even an updated organization chart to understand the company's hierarchy.

pros: The FNC Leadership team centrally located in Richardson, TX which made it less of a challenge to present, discuss, or escalate issues / concerns.
cons: Way too many political agendas for the size of the company.   They preach that people are their primary concern and interest, but the actions do not support their words.  They are a manufacturing company first and do not want to invest in the necessary skills to become a top Services / Solutions company.  There is minimal to zero employee development.

review_title: Little recognition and sub par wages
pros: When not tied up with ridiculous process and policies, pretty good working environment with a lot of nice colleagues. Decent flexibility on working arrangements and work life balance.
cons: Technical staff are not properly recognised for the work that they do and definitely not paid accordingly or anywhere near market rates. Seems to be a culture of top management take all and everyone else gets nothing. Very policy driven company, which can make things very difficult and portrays an obstructive image to customers and other external stakeholders.

review_title: An Organisation for Family members of Management
pros: No Swipe in.. Swipe out ...
cons:
Only Family members will get the best benefits..even if the management has to go out of the way to achieve that ! Bootlickers and management's relatives will get to go to Onsite and will get good appraisals!! no matter how hard you will work  you will get squat !! Every one in the company is someone's CHACHA,MAMA,BHAI,BAHAN,AUNTY,UNCLE.!.. Managment is very unprofessional..! Specially the MIDDLE MANAGMENT ! J
Also I will talk about the Resource management , they treat consultants like vegetables, They will put you on some project in remote location without your consent..and even sometimes without giving you prior notice about your transfer! ..you will work their like you are digging a coal mine..will make you  stay in a room shared by 2 other people !
Join this company only if you know how to play with Nepotism and all other things I listed above.

review_title: A way to go yet but getting there
pros: Having Duncan Tait at the helm is paying dividends - he walks the walk and has been instrumental at introducing some positive changes: he's also well respected. Because of its Japanese heritage, the company is more focused on longer term outcomes rather than short term wins. I feel valued and respected
cons: It is still not as innovative as it could be. Some areas of the business including delivery teams hinge around capabilities of a few good individuals to deliver. The way it  has handled staff consultation on key issues is inconsistent and morale has suffered in  some areas but i suspect this is no different to similar organisations

review_title: A place of no strategic direction
pros: Well as paid as a senior manager.
cons:
Password reset and windows server patching are core business of this company 
No strategic direction what's so ever
Believer of low level IT contract
No project management or governance
Senior management is reluctant to undertake any project work
Although there are senior management on innovation but no real innovation at all. 
No practice management in any area of IT or governance 
Solution Architects are mostly busy with excel spreadsheet to calculate number of servers. There is no real architecture what's so ever. 
Do not believe in cloud computing strategy 
Career development is no-existence 
20 years behind any competitor 
Company culture is profit by any means not about employees who generate profit

job_title: Senior Manager, Government Relations in Washington, DC
pros: Great work/life balance in Washington, DC.  Good people. Fascinating technology policy issue set. Opportunities to travel to Japan, Germany, and London. Good access to key trade associations and networking.
cons: Large Japanese conglomerate.  "Galapagos effect"--all the cool technology and ideas are trapped in Japan and in Japanese and don't migrate globally via English. Age and experience is value over youth and activity. Very internally disjointed. Old and depreciating facilities. Low-middle benefits and no equity.

pros: Stability and not too much work pressure. Decent pay and bonuses. If you want to spend some quite time in life than yes this is a great company to be in. There are some decent people working here but most of the people are taking it easy. I don't blame them as the work is cyclical and work comes in spurts. Additionally, its a small place and you will get to know almost every one.
cons: Management is not competent and folks who are politically active are the ones that get promotion. No processes in place for promotions and work is almost never appreciated.

review_title: Look elsewhere, unless you are or are about to be living in a homeless shelter.
pros: The only reason would be if you were unemployed, had no other current opportunities, and need the paycheck.
cons: You are not working at a consulting firm, you are working for a temp/staff augmentation firm and you will be laid off 15 seconds after they can no longer bill others for hours of your life. Do not fall for any of their recruiter's lies that they are 'project-based'. They are a body shop, and when they cannot bill a client for your time, your options are very limited and it would be an excellent time to brush up the resume and get it out there. There is no career path per se, and even the managers I had when I was there (2002-2007) have moved on to other opportunities.

review_title: Some-what ineffective management and missing accountability
pros:

-May hinder future career prospects if you encounter problems with management
-Has just lost the DWP government contract (job security is now out of the question then?)

job_title: Test Engineer II in Richardson, TX

The telecom industry is going through a lot of change now. FNC makes sure its employees are well equipped for whats coming. The salary is great. There is portals here where you can post your ideas and they get noticed and implemented. You will be recognized for all the hard work you put in. All the people I work with here are encouraging. I am excited to get to work every day morning(even on Monday!! ;))
cons: Till now I have not experienced anything bad working here.

review_title: Glad to be out of there!
pros: Some good people still work there, but not many!
cons:

Typical Boys Club untrained managers, with small minds.  
Big egos, but no backbone!  Do as I say mentality or else!  
Management are bullies.  
Performance reviews are a joke and are not related to remuneration. 
Constantly lose existing contracts and cannot secure any new large contracts due to their bad reputation. 
Constant layoffs, the company is a third of the size it was 5 years ago.

review_title: Fujitsu NZ, a shame to the IT industry....
pros:
Quick and hassle free joining.

A platform for dummies that will teach, "how stuff works in corporate".

review_title: Can be a great company but often fails to fulfil potential
pros:
Work life balance can be very good if you work in the right department and have good management.

Salary is market average or below but bonus can be very good for an IT company if financial targets are met.

cons:
Management is inconsistent, often changing the organisation for the sake of it.
Risk averse organisation unwilling to invest big.
Very process heavy
If you don't push, salary increases are often below inflation and can quickly fall well below the median.

review_title: A GOOD EMPLOYER WHO VALUES WORK LIFE BALANCE
pros:
A real inclusive environment to work in with flexible working, and development. 

A huge scope of work across multiple customer bases, and verticals.

If you are a self starter, then plenty of opportunity to develop, or lead projects.
cons:
A haphazard approach with distributed systems that are not fully integrated. 

Everything is a manual process, no toolsets, or automation to help get things done quickly. 

No standard templates, or processes with every solution a manual re-invent the wheel exercise. 

Strategy driven centrally from Japan, with this not always aligned with the view from customers worldwide.

review_title: The end is nigh for Fujitsu America technical support.

cons: Poor level of communication all around in the company. Changes are often made without notice to the employees. Poor level of documentation, disorganized, no clear direction/push to unclutter the current documentation that's being utilized and reported on.

pros: Lots of good people in the consulting ranks willing to help in a collaborative manner.
cons: Lots, too many to list here.  Upper management in the ERP consulting ranks are out of touch with the general consulting ranks, the vision doesn't get passed into the consulting level. Management style that upper management employ boarder on the bullying.  Leaderships direct reports are too scared to say anything, it's my way or the highway. Consultants are not willing to go the extra mile for leadership and only worried about their jobs and most looking to get out.  Bullying only works for a short time.

review_title: Poor Management - STAY AWAY from this company

- communication sent re townhall states food would be served, but not evern bottled waters were given to the employees

review_title: IT giant but needs more joined up thinking
pros: Large accounts and some very big names on the client list. The company has a strong and rich technology heritage and invests a considerable amount of time and money on innovative products. Some of its current offerings are very mature and offer customers with excellent services - for example Managed Service Desk.
cons: Not very agile in the market place and often too focussed on its own solutions instead of the customers' actual requirements. Very much a home for technologists and service managers but not a company well structured or suited to major change programmes.

pros: Low stress. Somewhat autonomous roles. Ability to work from home. Due to poor hires over the years, it is very easy to look good. It is a large name known throughout the world.
cons:
Cheap. 1% (or less) salary raises in a market that bears an average of 4.1%, in a country that averages over 3%, in 2013. And those raises are usually delayed for 6-8 months, so it is not an annual raise. 
Ineptly run. 
Majority of hires are inexperienced and low skilled developers (cheapness wins again). 
Zero training. 
Bonuses for employees were eliminated in 2012. 
An old boys club.
Very behind the times. 
In Calgary, the most booming city in Canada, the business continues to decline and they continue to lay people off.
Lots of politics and people "protecting" themselves at the expense of others.
Maximum 4 weeks holidays.
No August long weekend.
No personal time off.

pros: Nothing much about pros because I haven't work in that company yet.
cons: Waste company I have ever seen .Long back they have conducted off campus and I've been selected in that but the worst part is after I've send my details like certificates etc ...they were not in a position to send me call letter then why the need of recruiting the fresher's and why the hell wasting their valuable time .you people have your own reasons I.e internal structing etc then you should select minimum number students who you can give them employability .As far as I knw urs is a big company but doing like this will never increase your fame.bad experience

pros: Top tier global IT company to add to a resume.  Management is relatively open to alternative working methods, telecommuting, flex hours etc.
cons:
Hard to know where to begin on this topic.  

As so many others have mentioned there is no reward for job performance or opportunity for growth unless you are in the right circle.  

Management is disengaged from their operations  - For instance, I have been reporting to my current manager for about 4 years now and can count on one hand the number of times we have been in the same room and on the phone is only slightly better.  

Constant reorganization.

Total absence of internal promotion.

Pay is below 75% to the median in the industry by title (again unless you are in the right circle).

Titles are do not correlate with responsibilities.

Management is deceptive.

Employee engagement and salary improvement initiatives come and go without action being taken.

pros:
Fujitsu hire really talented people.
Great projects, lots of good technology. Lots of opportunity to learn new tech.
As many people stay there of well over 10 years they are very good at supporting you on a personal level. (I raised a family whilst there).
cons:
Management promise career progression but unless you are in with the right people it won't happen.
Be prepared to sit in the same job/role for many, many years.
Lots of posters about career paths that look glossy but end up in the basement cafe behind the stairs.
Only way to get a promotion is to leave and come back.

review_title: learnt a lot but frustrations grow
pros: Big company does big things - I get involved in developing global cloud platforms from the ground-up.
cons: Silos - several groups around the world doing the same thing. Lack of information sharing. Difficult to get (useful) information out of Japan - they always put a few clueless contact persons in between to ensure things get lost in translation and going back and forth takes ages. Quality and fear of regressions stifles progress.

review_title: An unlearning experience - You will forget your core expertise in days
pros:
Laidback culture
No unnecessary deductions in salary
Friendly peers
Good appraisals
cons:
No growth or learning opportunities in the infrastructure management projects. You will learn nothing and keep on doing clerical and mundane jobs. Your technical acumen or your core domain expertise will not be used and you will be expected to work on any technology by just referring to How to docs.

Pathetic or non existent transport facilities. They will make cringe and cry with their transport services and would expect you to thank them for providing the skeleton services.

review_title: Good environment, friendly but no ambition towards career progression.
job_title: Software & Solutions Developer in Swansea, Wales
pros:
Good environment with a decent outdoor view, equipment required is available. 
People are local and friendly including customer, average age of early 30s, very few grads.
Company looks good on the CV.
Salary can be good depending on how you sell yourself and experience at the start.
Pay raise yearly depending on performance.
Great packages; car allowance, bonus, pension etc.
cons:
Not the best place to be if you wish to climb the career ladder.
People here are not ambitious.
It's hard to get noticed and even if you meet all objectives and get put forward for promotion the chance of getting it is very slim.

review_title: Worst Company in my last three companies.
pros:
Annual hike is slightly better as compare to Indian companies like TCS,INFY etc.
Flexi timing  depending on your project.
cons:
The worst is their Bangalore facility. No canteen,No transport,Office seems to be a third class company.
They hire freshers at 1.5 LPA, so not a good talent pool they have.
No projects.
Their Notice period is three month.My employee manager,ex project manager both get fired due to long time on bench.I was also on bench when I resigned they starts forcing me to serve full three month notice period.
On one side they are firing Bench resources and on the other side if one bench resource has resigned you are forcing him to serve full three months notice period.

Never join this company if you have any other offer.You will definitely gonna repent your decision if you join this company.

review_title: Good company with some poor managers
pros: Interesting work with pretty good remuneration. A generally open and supportive environment.
cons: I was driven crazy by a micro manager who, despite my experience and good reviews, couldn't let me just get on with my job. He is the only reason I left. I was otherwise pretty happy.

pros: Been very fair with respect to accommodating work / life balance. Varied work with little or no oversight. Bonus payments annually could be a lot more competitive but at least I have had them every year for 10 years bar 2. Interesting work providing you dont expect to be spoon-fed it but go and look for it. Excellent colleagues and inspirational line manager and directors.
cons: Not the best paid but job security until now has not been an issue. I have worked for IBM and Sun where job losses and threats of redundancy happened on a monthly basis.

pros: None. This is a company with a serious lack of attitude!
cons: Hierarchical to the nth degree, total lack of sales drive, no passion, bureaucratic, process bound, accepting of mediocrity as a norm, too many people waiting to retire. There is an over-riding atmosphere of torpor and inertia. Lots of people thinking they are very sophisticated and high brow, where in actual fact they are pen pushing civil servant types who have no value outside of the institutionalised wall of ICL - sorry, Fujitsu. There is an incredible smugness amongst the middle and senior managers that they are vastly superior. Unfortunately they are not and need to be exposed to a few harsh truths from the outside. There is huge potential here and Duncan Tait is a very good CEO, but he is pushing water uphill right now.

review_title: Great for Learning, Poor at Progression
pros: There is no doubt that everyone that works at FCL is driven and customer-focused. Management also tries to ensure that training opportunities are widely available to all staff, though it is up to each person to get their own training done and to champion their development.
cons: It is hard to launch ideas for new services and solutions because of the inherent bureaucracy. Most initiatives are driven top-down rather than bottom up. Because of the fact that most persons already work long hours, it also difficult to justify reward and recognition programmes in a conventional way.

review_title: A great company to work for - if not for the Agenda 2020 Redundancy Plan
job_title: Service Desk Agent in Manchester, England
pros: This is a company with some great facilities and amenities (even access to a gym at work). Being a multinational implementing agile principles and various career pathways it is a good place for growth.
cons: Unfortunately, everything at Fujitsu at the moment is looking gloomy as the management intends to cut down on cost via redundancy plans on it's human resources which affect at least 2000 employees in UK where I work for.

review_title: Great client base and reputation, mileage may vary depending on your skills
pros: Good training internally, learn and work with a great consulting framework that will give good exposure to project management and delivery. Good a place as any to cut your teeth.
cons: Pay was very very low compared to competitors. Internal politics and lack of regard for employees welfare from middle management can cause some friction. Not a great software development capability which limits career potential in some cases.

review_title: So much promise but they just cant deliver
pros: Great product.  Great story.
cons: They just dont know how to sell in the US.  There is no effective marketing or demand gen.  They release products with no go to market strategy in place, no press release, just a "hey, go sell this" attitude.  Every conversation begins with "Fujitsu does that?" so while our competitors are selling their solutions we are stuck explaining who Fujitsu is and why they didn't know we were in that market segment.

pros:
Generally good people to work with.
Hours were pretty flexible and accomodating.
cons:
Programming practices are very old and stodgy.
Use of Macroscope documentation is cumbersome and not something you would ever use again. And just because you put Word templates on the web, does not make it a "Cloud Solution"!
Some training potential, except that none of it ever gets scheduled.
Tends to value people who are senior and stick around over young new talent, but needs to recognize that some who stick around aren't doing it for the passion, but do it because they've fallen too far behind and have nowhere else to go!

review_title: Great people, not so great work culture
pros: Fujitsu is very fortunate to have a great number of dedicated and very intelligent employees who know their jobs very well. Benefits are very good and employees are trusted to work remotely and without micro-management.
cons: Too much turnover in management and a lack of leadership and vision for mid and lower level employees. No budget to hire additional employees to help accomplish already overburdened workloads. Too much time spent trying to get a square peg to fit a round hole. No room for advancement professionally and no emphasis made to personal or professional development.

pros:
-still can be considered as low-end-T1 vendor where you can learn the processes(soft skills)
-Learn  all the office politics skills from own team leader and manager
cons:
-Got an out of recycle 10% pay raise a (approved by the CEO)  but got layoff less than a year later...(also got great feedback from customer)
-A lot off restructuring and some managers got promotion but never got any impact
-Very bad culture where people want to argue instead of helping customers or colleague

pros: Ease of work,increments, work culture
cons: Management in India is mostly Pune based hence if you are at any other location there will be no visibility. Also all management is from Tech mahindra so dont except anything innovative. You will find many old employees in management with no skills or real world worth but highly political. Guess thats how they survived for so long.

job_title: Senior Solutions Architect in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Employees at some locations are shown respect and have flexibility in their work. (Although this is not universally true and other sites have declined into micro management.)
cons: The company has lost its way and is in a state of continuous panicked reorganisation.  It has fallen behind its peers in salary and benefits and has an overly bureaucratic administration fronted by implacable and faceless IT systems.

review_title: OK if you like confused matrix structures
job_title: Senior Commercial Manager in Bracknell, England
pros:
Pleasant working surroundings
Reasonable benefits package
Positive attitude to corporate responsibility & diversity with matching corporate activities
cons:
Matrix structures within functions - at times reporting to Account Director, Divisional Functional Director & also then a Line Manager outside the

review_title: Overall not a bad place to work.

Access to training courses - eg. 1 external week's training per year, eg Microsoft, ITIL courses.

Office building could do with a re-vamp.
Good people being let leave and paying replacements higher salaries.  If they would give proper salary increases to current staff,  the current attrition may not be an issue.

review_title: Urgent Upgrade in Management Culture and Procedures highly needed!
job_title: Service Desk Expert in Lisbon, Lisbon District
pros: Relaxed environment. Decent pay. Initial learning period.  Personal connection to customers.
cons: Terrible incompetent Portuguese management only slowing down progress. Lying, manipulating and selfish thinking are the main tools used. Nearly a total lack of eye for simple progress and development. Never experienced anything like it, especially in a huge international IT company.  Meetings after meetings, but no action.

review_title: Great place to work for career development
pros: Fujitsu Computer Products of America has a collaberative environment.  There is great open communication between employees of all levels.  Feedback on job performance and progress is provided on a regular basis from management.  Pay here is fair and there are bonuses.  Benefits are great and you have PTO versus sicktime and vacation for those that care.
cons: The downsides of working at Fujitsu Computer Products of America are nothing, it's a great place to work.  Where you can find job satisfaction and career growth.  There are great friendly people that are willing to help if you have questions or need other guidance.

review_title: Good place to work if you turn a blind eye to how the company is run
job_title: Senior Manager in Pearl River, NY
pros: You get to work on advanced technology  (ROADM, OTN, Data services).  You have some latitude in how you execute your work. Acceptance of new process ideas.
cons: Overtime is expected for some disciplines. Engineering/planning are very silo'd. No clear communications what the customer is really looking for in a product. Very political; some managers/directors very protective of their turf, at times to the detriment of the company.

pros: As a leader in the transport space FNC is working hard to maintain this leadership role. One avenue is to add services - data services (ELINE, ELAN, SOAM....) and OTN. This provides ample opportunities to get involved with new/different technologies. FNC is in a position where there are more things to do than staff, so finding exciting things to do is very easy if you are interested.
cons: The Japanese business culture can be difficult to deal with. They ask a lot of questions and you are often left wondering why they are asking.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Burlington, MA
pros: Ability to work from home several days a week.  Decent base pay.
cons: They have the most dysfunctional management I have ever seen.  They are cowardly and back stabbing.  They bad mouth others when they are not around.   More often than not your commissions are paid late, and each year it takes months to even get new comp plan arranged and during this time no commissions are paid.  Each department in company is so siloed and wary of each other and leads to distrust and morale issues.

review_title: Lisbon GDC - Literally depends on your manager. If this turns the wrong way for any reason there's no place to turn to
job_title: Helpdesk Technician/Service Desk Agent in Lisbon, Lisbon District
pros: Relatively stable. If the contract you're working on gets to an end you can apply internally to any open vacancies before the externals do.
cons: There is no effective progression system in place. You depend exclusively on your manager and there is no workaround it.

job_title: Senior Program Manager in Richardson, TX
pros:
- PTO policy, you start with 18 days up to 28 when you have been serving for 10+ years, on top of that company closes for 2 weeks on Christmas.
- Great company for seniors: many departments look like the star-ship Enterprise at "Star Trek VI: the undiscovered country", just on the verge of retirement. Quite a generous 401K where the company will fund a 3.5% on a DRA, even if you don't contribute... catch 22 is that you need to be there 6 years to have it all vested, great if you are in your mid 50's looking for your last job.
- very favorable to veterans, many managers served in the armed forces and will definitely pick a veteran above anyone else
- Cubicles are pretty big
- Great for women, FNC support all the affirmative action programs, WIN and so forth, very likely you will get hired or promoted over your male counterpars because of it
- Great company for managers: pretty much all your job will be making reports for Japan and approving travel reports, the real mid term and strategic decisions are made by the Japanese overloards, very few managers actually have the power to make any significant decission or take any risk
- Gym is quite nice, new and cheap plus some trails to run around the campus
- Overall very stable, there are many many old timers that have been 15+ or 20+ years in the company
- Good internship program, although several interns end up being sons/daughters or brothers/sisters or senior managers
- Great company for sales managers, you don't have bonus cap, so theoretically, you could make many thousands in commissions... although sales overall have been going down for years
cons:
- Bureaucracy and politics have a new dimension as not only you have to deal with local management but also report to the real managers: Fujitsu Japan. 
- Over-reporting, many times I felt like "office space", having to report and explain the same thing to 4-5 different managers, plus the joy of calls with Japan late in the afternoon to go over the same things.
- Too "many chiefs for very Indians", the amount of VPs and directors is incredible, although in reality, most directors would be managers in other companies and most VPs would have the equivalent title of Director anywhere else. 
- 'Good ole boys' company, if you have an old timer buddy from FNC or Nortel that work here, maybe a great place to be, not such a great place if you actually try to bring any kind of idea/method of working and get it implemented and approved throughout all the red tape
- Promotions and merit increases are based on who you know and political alliances, otherwise the joke around is that merit increases are "inflation adjustments"
- There is no training program for individuals, sometimes there will be a training course, usually given by someone who used to work at FNC and started a training company or is best buddies with one of the VPs, and there will be some high level 1-2 course where 20-30 people will attend, that's all.
- Ship is sinking, decreasing sales, increasing amount of lay offs (Pearl River office was just shut down), new products are not selling well at all yet (both HW and SW)
